meanings.definition: Depriving someone of the right to vote.
meanings.sent1: By not allowing certain people to vote, they are disenfranchising them.
meanings.sent2: The law disenfranchised many citizens by restricting their voting rights.
meanings.sent3: It would be quite disenfranchising if only a select few could participate in the election.
meanings.sent4: The new policy was like disenfranchising a whole community from having a say.
meanings.sent5: The act of disenfranchising can lead to feelings of powerlessness and frustration.

meanings.definition: Excluding someone from a group or activity.
meanings.sent1: The club's strict rules ended up disenfranchising many potential members.
meanings.sent2: She felt disenfranchised when her friends didn't invite her to the party.
meanings.sent3: Being the only one not chosen for the team was quite disenfranchising.
meanings.sent4: It's like disenfranchising someone from a game they were excited to play.
meanings.sent5: The act of disenfranchising can lead to feelings of loneliness and isolation.

meanings.definition: Taking away power or rights from someone.
meanings.sent1: The dictator's actions were disenfranchising the citizens of their basic freedoms.
meanings.sent2: The new policy was seen as disenfranchising the employees from their decision-making abilities.
meanings.sent3: It would be quite disenfranchising if someone took away your ability to make choices.
meanings.sent4: The corrupt officials were slowly disenfranchising the population of their voice.
meanings.sent5: The act of disenfranchising can lead to feelings of helplessness and injustice.
